title: Bipartisan House Coalition Votes to Repeal Health Law's Cadillac Tax
summary: Business- and labor-backed measure would cancel levy on high-cost employer insurance. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives overwhelmingly voted to repeal the "Cadillac tax" on high-cost employer health insurance, removing a piece of the Affordable Care Act that never took effect.

title: Pentagon Sending 2,100 Active-Duty National Guard Troops to Border
summary: Move will put border deployment at nearly 6,000. The Pentagon is sending more than 2,100 additional troops to the southwest border to augment the military force already there, officials said Wednesday.

title: Netflix Reports First Drop in U.S. Users in Nearly a Decade
summary: Video service blames slower-than-expected growth in part on its programming lineup. For the first time in nearly a decade, the number of people subscribing to Netflix Inc. in the U.S. declined, an underwhelming performance for the streaming giant that comes as a slew of rivals are about to enter the field.

title: Biden Goes Half Way to BernieCare
summary: The Democratic debate over single payer is over when, not whether.. Joe Biden's new health-care plan is supposed to show his moderation, not that this is a virtue to progressives. Hence the back and forth this week between Mr. Biden and Bernie Sanders about single payer. But cut through the spin, and the only debate Democrats are having is whether to eliminate private health insurance in one blow or on the installment plan.

title: A Coup at Planned Parenthood
summary: The abortion lobby dumps its president as insufficiently political.. Progressives are hurtling to the left so fast that even liberals in good standing are casualties of the tornado. Witness the coup this week at Planned Parenthood, which is a tacit reminder that the group is less a health-care outfit than a political lobby.

title: Pompeo Gets Religion
summary: A new international alliance to promote 'the first freedom.'. The State Department is holding its second Ministerial to Advance Religious Freedom this week, and on Thursday Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will announce a new International Religious Freedom Alliance. Its mission will be to find ways to promote this most basic of human rights-and hold abusers accountable.

title: House Holds Ross, Barr in Contempt Over Citizenship Question
summary: Oversight Committee continues its probe of the administration's effort, dropped last week by Trump. WASHINGTON-The House voted to hold Attorney General William Barr and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross in criminal contempt over their refusal to produce documents concerning the addition of a citizenship question to the census, days after President Trump abandoned his legal efforts to amend the survey.

title: Amazon Faces Probe in Europe Over Use of Merchant Data
summary: EU to investigate use of third-party sellers' data as scrutiny of tech firms mounts on both sides of the Atlantic. Amazon.com Inc. faces a European Union antitrust investigation into its treatment of merchants that sell goods on its site, the latest push by the bloc against a U.S. tech giant and the biggest regulatory threat thus far to the online retailer's growing market power.

title: Sanders Defends Medicare for All, Drawing Contrast With Biden
summary: Senator takes more confrontational tack, pushing back against criticism of his signature health-care idea. WASHINGTON-Sen. Bernie Sanders forcefully defended Medicare for All from escalating attacks on his signature health-care proposal.

title: Chinese Esports Group Backed by Tencent Raises $775 Million in U.S. IPO
summary: DouYu's listing was the biggest this year by a Chinese company in the U.S.. A Chinese video-streaming service raised $775 million through a Nasdaq listing, capitalizing on the growing popularity of watching others play games on the internet.

title: IBM Revenue Lags as Cloud Pivot Remains a Challenge
summary: Despite revenue decline, profit exceeded Wall Street estimates. International Business Machines Corp. said revenue fell for its fourth straight quarter as it struggles to retool its business for the modern computing age, although Big Blue's profit grew more than Wall Street had projected.

title: U.S. Ejects Turkey From F-35 Fighter Program
summary: White House says Ankara's purchase of a Russian air-defense system prompted move, sparking a protest from Ankara. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration formally ejected Turkey from the American-led F-35 Joint Strike Fighter program over Ankara's decision to purchase a Russian air-defense system, prompting a protest from Turkish officials.

title: Forget the Gold Standard and Make the Dollar Stable Again
summary: Precious metals no longer make sense as a store of value. Instead, peg money to goods and services.. Some of President Trump's potential nominees to the Federal Reserve Board have expressed sympathy for a return to the gold standard. Conventional monetary-policy experts deride the idea-and not wholly without reason. The gold standard won't work for a 21st-century monetary and financial system. It is possible, however, to emulate its best features without actually restoring the gold standard.

title: Why We Need Someone Like Ike
summary: War is likelier in a world without inhibition, and the cyber era has elevated undisciplined leaders.. Markets soar even as everyone panics about geopolitics. The same interconnectivity that has wrought fabulous wealth also allows political crises to migrate from one corner of the globe to another. As technology defeats distance, the new digital world is smaller, more anxious and more claustrophobic than ever.

title: EBay Lifts Profit Outlook Amid Tepid Revenues
summary: The online marketplace benefited from having 4% more buyers. EBay Inc. raised its profit outlook and notched better-than-expected quarterly results, but continued to show sluggish revenue growth.

title: AOC Is the Gift That Keeps Giving
summary: ICE isn't enough. She wants to do away with the Department of Homeland Security.. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez doesn't think much of the agencies that keep America safe. New Yorker editor David Remnickrecently asked about her call to abolish U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Couldn't ICE be reformed? No, replied the freshman Democrat. "The core structure of ICE" and "the entire Department of Homeland Security" are "large threats to American civil liberties."

title: Trump Can't Make Peace by Wishing the Palestinians Away
summary: If he wants to broker the 'deal of the century,' he has to oppose Israeli plans to annex the West Bank.. The Kingdom of Bahrain hosted what U.S. organizers called a Peace to Prosperity Economic Workshop. The June conference, which aimed to propose a plan for stability to the Middle East through economic development, was the brainchild of Jared Kushner, President Trump's son-in-law and close adviser. An impressive U.S. delegation traveled to Manama, the capital, for the occasion.

title: Who'll Take a Pay Cut for Free College?
summary: 'It's so inspiring, I'd do it for nothing.' Put that piety to a test.. Democratic candidates for president, in their impressive expansiveness, are promising free college. Some limit their proposals to community colleges, others to state-run schools, and a few, going for broke, want also to forgive student debt for private-college tuition. Since no realm of American life has undergone greater inflation in recent decades than higher education, this is no piddling promise. The cost to taxpayers could be in the trillions, though the prospect would please a nephew of mine who this autumn is sending a son to Dartmouth at the annual price of $76,000.

title: 'The Chinese Lady' Review: A Glimpse of a Far Land
summary: Afong Moy, the ﬁrst Chinese woman in the United States, was paraded before American audiences as an object of fascination.. In late 1834, Afong Moy would sit daily in the parlor of a lower Manhattan home. Dressed in an elegant silk tunic and trousers, her hair tightly pulled up into a bun and her bound feet shod in tiny slippers, the recently arrived traveler from China reportedly received 2,000 visitors per week during a three-month stay in New York. Making small talk with such numbers, were it required of her, would have likely exhausted the young woman, who had little facility in English. But these were not social calls: Afong Moy was billed as the first Chinese woman in the United States, and members of the public paid 50 cents each for a glimpse of her.

title: Sen. Warren's Good Work for Dow Chemical
summary: She doesn't deserve to be vilified for helping the maker of silicone breast implants.. I don't support Elizabeth Warren or her policies, but earlier this week the Washington Post ran a piece suggesting she's a corporate shill in socialist's clothing. As a longtime communications director for two Washington-based trade associations that work to limit the economic damage done by avaricious plaintiffs' lawyers and so-called expert witnesses, I must come to her defense.

title: Three States Sue Trump Administration Over Federal Tax Changes
summary: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say IRS targeted them for attempted workaround to cap on SALT deductions. New Jersey, New York and Connecticut filed a federal lawsuit challenging the U.S. Treasury Department's move to block the states' attempted workaround of a key part of the 2017 federal tax law.

title: House Passes Resolutions Blocking Arms Sales to Gulf Allies
summary: Three votes aim to prevent U.S. weapons sales to Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates; presidential veto is likely. WASHINGTON-The House sent President Trump a trio of resolutions Wednesday aimed at blocking arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, joining the Senate in disapproving of administration ties to the Gulf nations but setting up a likely presidential veto.

title: Lawsuit Against Whole Foods Is Thrown Out
summary: Judge says New York City probe wasn't sufficient proof grocer cheated plaintiff. A federal judge in Manhattan threw out a lawsuit accusing Whole Foods of overcharging for prepackaged cheeses and cupcakes, saying a New York City investigation accusing the grocer of overstating food weight isn't sufficient proof the plaintiff had been ripped off.

title: New York City Gears Up for Weekend Heat Wave
summary: Temperatures likely will hit triple digits, raising fears of another blackout. New York City is expected to get its first heat wave of the summer in the coming days. Temperatures likely will hit triple-digits this weekend, raising fears of another blackout like last week's outage.

title: Mexico Spurns Private Oil-Drilling Partners
summary: López Obrador's government effectively rolled back key parts of a 2014 constitutional overhaul that ended a state oil-industry monopoly. MEXICO CITY-Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador effectively rolled back key parts of a 2014 constitutional overhaul that ended a state oil-industry monopoly and let private firms find and pump oil for the first time in seven decades.

title: Mayor Stays Mum on Whether Officer in Eric Garner Case Should Be Fired
summary: New York's Bill de Blasio withholds 'personal opinions' about fate of the NYPD's Daniel Pantaleo. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday declined to say whether he thinks the police officer accused of placing Eric Garner in a deadly chokehold should be fired.

title: Trump Rests His 2020 Hopes on Some Old Tactics
summary: President bets he doesn't have to change his rhetoric or policies to win a second term, just make his opponents appear unacceptable to voters. WASHINGTON-President Trump's aides say he didn't set out to spark a firestorm Sunday morning with his series of racial insults on Twitter. But his message was consistent with the broader wager he has placed on his own re-election.

title: MTA Overhaul May Include 2,700 Job Cuts
summary: Board members are expected to debate and vote on the proposal when they meet next week. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority could cut up to 2,700 jobs over the next few years, according to a proposed overhaul of the nation's largest transit agency released Wednesday.

title: Consumer Watchdog Wants to Work With Financial Companies to Encourage Saving
summary: Consumer advocates criticized the proposed partnerships, saying a strong agency was needed to police the industry. WASHINGTON-The federal consumer agency set up after the financial crisis to oversee the financial industry wants to work with firms on joint research to encourage people to save more.

title: FASB Votes to Delay Credit Loss Standard for Some Lenders
summary: Small public banks would receive an extra three years to prepare for accounting change. The Financial Accounting Standards Board is poised to give lenders more time to prepare for the implementation of a new rule that would require them to record expected future losses as soon as loans are issued.

title: San Francisco Delays 'IPO Tax' Measure
summary: Sponsor of plan intended to address inequality plans to put it back on the ballot in 2020 with changes making it easier to pass. SAN FRANCISCO-Facing a backlash from the business community, city officials here have tabled until next year a proposed ballot measure to raise a tax on stock compensation to address concerns over wealth disparity.

title: When Critics Err
summary: Sometimes the greatest challenge critics face isn't making sense of the new but overcoming the prejudices of their own taste..

title: Lighthizer Charms Congress, but Struggles to Sell USMCA
summary: Trump's point man on U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade pact woos Democrats leery of deal's fine points. title: Pelosi Says Deal on Debt Ceiling, Spending Levels Needed by Friday
summary: House speaker aims to pass legislation ahead of looming summer recess. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi set a Friday deadline for Congress and the Trump administration to reach an agreement on raising the U.S. government's borrowing limit and setting new overall spending levels.

title: Proposed Weinstein Settlement May Not Include Two Accusers
summary: As negotiators maneuver to advance multimillion-dollar settlement, one plaintiff's lawyer vows to fight 'sham deal'. title: New Clinic for Drug Users Opens Near Penn Station
summary: Housing Works, a social-services group known for its thrift stores, is behind the one-stop site. In a nondescript Midtown building tucked between tourist hotels and a few short blocks from New York Penn Station is one of the oldest syringe-exchange programs in the city and one of the newest primary-care clinics for drug users and the homeless.

summary: The classic ambient album receives a reissue that includes a full disc of new material as gorgeous as the original record..

title: Front-Runner List to Lead IMF Narrows to Eurozone Candidates

The list of front-runners to succeed Christine Lagarde as head of the International Monetary Fund has narrowed to four eurozone officials, according to several senior European officials.

title: Ebola Epidemic in Congo Declared a Global Health Emergency
summary: World Health Organization says outbreak has infected more than 2,500 people and killed nearly 1,700 of them. The World Health Organization on Wednesday declared the Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo a global public-health emergency, a rare move that seeks to mobilize more funds to stop the deadly virus nearly a year after it first took hold in a region marked by decades of conflict.

title: Stocks Lower as Earnings Season Starts With Growth Concerns
summary: Industrial sector is one of the biggest drags on S&P 500; earnings are due from Netflix, eBay and others.. U.S. stocks fell as the start of earnings season exposed weaknesses in the growth outlook for some companies.

summary: A lack of outside verification has frustrated marketers. Netflix Inc. only selectively releases unverifiable viewership numbers for its programming, arguing the majority of its audience data is its own business because it has no advertisers to please.

title: Foreign Buying of U.S. Homes Suffers Record Drop

title: Medical Distributors Stocks Fall After Opioid Data Reports
summary: Wednesday's drop puts pause on solid performance for medical distributors so far this year. Shares of medical distributors and other health-care companies took a hit on Wednesday, and their pain may not be short-lived.

title: Facebook Pressed on Protections for Cryptocurrency Users
summary: House lawmakers pursue regulatory concerns in second day of hearings on Libra. WASHINGTON-House lawmakers asked Facebook Inc. how it would protect users of its cryptocurrency, underscoring the political hurdles the company needs to clear before it can issue the digital cash.

title: Shale Output Shows Signs of Slowing
summary: The number of active oil rigs in the U.S. fell to a 17-month low last week. Oil prices are back on the rise, but shale drillers still have little incentive to ramp up activity.

title: Uranium Regains Some Glow as Trump Sidesteps Trade Fight
summary: U.S. president holds back from imposing limits and prices climb. Uranium prices jumped to a four-month high after President Trump held back from imposing limits on U.S. imports of the nuclear fuel, saying he didn't regard it a national security risk.

title: Home Builders Get a Reality Check
summary: Shares of home builders have been on a tear this year, but fresh housing data could hold them back.. Shares of home builders have been on a tear this year. But fresh housing data could hold them back.

summary: Victim-compensation attorney has worked to determine payments in cases including 9/11 attacks. Boeing Co. has hired victim-compensation attorney Kenneth Feinberg to distribute $50 million to families who lost relatives in two crashes involving its 737 MAX planes.

title: Bank of New York Mellon's Revenue, Earnings Fall
summary: Shares rise 2% however as earnings-per-share exceed analyst estimates. Earnings at Bank of New York Mellon Corp. decreased in the company's second quarter as fee revenue slipped 3% from the same period a year ago.

title: One Time at Commie Camp...
summary: China's dictator heads to the beach. Meanwhile, a New York Times columnist gets nervous about 2020.. Chinese tyrant Xi Jinping is going to the beach to ponder a response to President Donald Trump's tariff diplomacy. A crucial question for Mr. Xi is whether he's going to have to deal with Mr. Trump for another five and a half years. In the U.S., even many Trump opponents suspect the answer is yes.

title: China's Didi Seeks Up to $2 Billion as Ride-Hailing Firms Want Investors to Fund Growth
summary: Fundraising would give the company a valuation of about $62 billion. China's dominant ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing Technology Co. is working to raise up to $2 billion from investors, according to people familiar with the matter, the latest sign that firms in the sector including Uber Technologies Inc. and Lyft Inc. are eager to raise money to fuel investments while posting steep losses.

title: Protesters Arrested at Hawaiian Mountain Over Massive Telescope
summary: Opponents say 'this is our most sacred mountain' ; Thirty Meter Telescope officials say care taken to respect rich history. Police began making arrests Wednesday at the base of Hawaii's tallest mountain, Mauna Kea, after hundreds of native Hawaiian protesters had gathered to stop the construction of a large telescope on what they say is their most sacred ground.

title: Italian, Greek Bonds Rally as Hunt for Yield Expands
summary: Some investors bought the securities because they are unwilling to buy safer bonds at increasingly negative yields. Investors are buying bonds from once-avoided European countries, spurred by expectations that ongoing easy-money policies from central banks will continue to fuel demand for debt.

title: Pakistan Arrests Militant Wanted by the U.S.
summary: Hafiz Saeed, who is linked to 2008 Mumbai attack, carries a $10 million U.S. bounty on his head. title: Madoff Investor Kingate to Pay Back $860 Million
summary: Settlement wraps up one of the largest remaining disputes in liquidation of Bernard Madoff's Ponzi scheme. One of the largest offshore fund managers that channeled cash to Bernard Madoff will return $860 million in stolen money under a settlement with the liquidators cleaning up after his Ponzi scheme.

title: Fed's George Suggests She's Not Ready to Cut Rates
summary: Markets are broadly expecting the central bank to lower its benchmark rate at the end of July. Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City President Esther George said Wednesday she's prepared to be flexible, but she doesn't yet see the case for a cut in interest rates later this month.

title: Fed's Beige Book Reports Modest Growth, Trade Worries
summary: Many businesses express optimism, but say they are keeping an eye on trade talks. American businesses see economic activity expanding modestly amid lingering fears over trade, according to a Federal Reserve report released Wednesday.

summary: Executives at both regional lenders say they expect Fed to cut rates this year, which would put pressure on bank earnings. Two of the largest regional lenders in the U.S. reported that strong borrowing spurred higher revenue and profits in the latest quarter.

title: Russia Denies Visas for U.S. Teachers at Moscow School
summary: American envoy urged Kremlin not to use children as 'pawns in diplomatic disputes'. MOSCOW-Russia has denied visas for teachers at a school in this capital city run by the U.S., British and Canadian embassies, adding to tensions between Washington and Moscow.

title: CSX Considers Promoting Interim Finance Chief
summary: Railroad, which named Kevin Boone interim CFO this year, is also conducting an external search. CSX Corp. is considering making its interim finance chief permanent, the company's chief executive said.

title: U.N. Nuclear Chief Set to Leave Amid Iran Standoff
summary: IAEA and its director general Yukiya Amano have come under increasing scrutiny over 2015 Iranian nuclear deal. The head of the United Nations' atomic agency is preparing to step down early, potentially kicking off a fight for control of the agency that has oversight of Iran's nuclear program, diplomats said.

title: After Paris's Clown Bar, a Second Act
summary: Chef Sota Atsumi, just 33, has been the culinary phenom behind one of Paris's toughest tables. Now he's left Clown Bar to open a place of his own: the Japanese-accented Maison. SOTA ATSUMI WANTS to invite you home. For the past two years the 33-year-old Japanese chef, whose signature custardy calves' brains and game-filled pithiviers helped make Clown Bar one of the hottest restaurants in Paris, has been developing a cozy new residence for his Japanese-accented French cuisine on a block in the city's 11th arrondissement. The restaurant, simply called Maison, will be a convivial setting for his most ambitious-and personal-cooking to date. It's "a relaxed place with a domestic ambience but serious food," says his wife and muse, Akiko Otsu, who works in fine-art printing.

title: Investigators Wrap Up Michael Cohen Campaign-Finance Probe
summary: Conclusion of probe, which interviewed figures in Trump's orbit, comes without any further indictments. The Manhattan U.S. attorney's office said it has completed its investigation into campaign-finance violations by Michael Cohen, President Trump's former lawyer, without announcing further indictments of figures in Mr. Trump's orbit.

title: Is Good as Gold the Right Model for the Fed?
summary: The historical record shows that the gold-standard years saw tremendous financial instability.. In "The Fed Could Use a Golden Rule" (op-ed, July 12), James Grant argues that under the gold standard stockholders in banks were responsible for bank solvency, whereas now, without gold backing the dollar, we have government bailouts.

title: Is There a Future for Girls in Girls' Sports?
summary: I have been devastated to see fellow women defeated in sporting competitions by male-bodied athletes who identify as women. This is deeply unfair to women and an insult to the rights our mothers and grandmothers have fought for.. Regarding Madeleine Kearns's "A Connecticut Girl Challenges Male Domination of Female Sports" (op-ed, July 12): Like many women, I stand in solidarity with Selina Soule, who has become a voice of reason and fairness in women's sports. As a gender-critical feminist, I believe gender is a social construct and, like most scientists and biologists, that sex is binary.

title: The Feds Have Helped Some Gerrymandering to Thrive
summary: With Eric Holder helping to lead the charge, a court agreed to change the boundaries of several districts to benefit Democrats in time for the Virginia House elections in November 2019.. Your editorial "Eric Holder's Judicial Gerrymanders" (July 8) overlooks Mr. Holder's recent success in Virginia. When Virginia's state legislative districts were drawn in 2011, they were passed with bipartisan majorities, including with the support of African-American members. Redistricting in Virginia, like in other Southern states, is subject to the federal Voting Rights Act of 1965, which requires U.S. Justice Department approval of district maps to ensure there is no racial gerrymandering. Virginia received this approval from the Justice Department in 2011, headed by then-Attorney General Eric Holder.

title: Why Pasta Salad Is Your Best Bet This Summer
summary: When it's done right, it's the star of the cookout. With these recipes from New York's Superiority Burger, who needs hot dogs?. THE PROBLEM WITH most pasta salad comes down to the pasta itself, said Brooks Headley, chef/owner of the New York's Superiority Burger.

title: Antitrust Must Address the Future Instead of the Past
summary: The Justice Department's lawsuit to block Quad Graphics' acquisition of LSC Communications, two leading printing companies, focuses on the past. With digital content outpacing print magazines and newspapers, the companies argue the merger is necessary to survive.. Your editorial "Justice's Antitrust Confusion" (July 9) correctly shows that U.S. antitrust enforcers are wrongly pursuing antitrust cases against local televisions mergers, which are now but small players compared with the massively scalable Google and Facebook . This dynamic is also at work in the Justice Department's lawsuit to block Quad Graphics' acquisition of LSC Communications-two leading printing companies. With digital content outpacing print magazines and newspapers, the companies argue the merger is necessary to survive, using what is known as a "failing firm" merger.

title: Signing of Sudan Accord Begins Anxious Wait for Democracy
summary: Military and protesters seal pact on path to elections in 2022. Rani Farah quit a lucrative job in Saudi Arabia, spent two months in jail and took a bullet to the chest, all to bring democracy to his country Sudan after 30 years of dictatorship.

title: Retired Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens Dies
summary: Stevens, 99, made a towering impression on American law during 34 years on the Supreme Court. summary: Mortgage rates have rarely been so low, yet the housing market remains subdued. Lower interest rates were supposed to breathe new life into the housing market. But so far there are few signs of a real-estate revival.

title: China's State-Driven Growth Model Is Running Out of Gas
summary: Latest data suggest China may not match the trajectory of Taiwan, South Korea and Japan. New data showing the toll trade tensions are taking on China's economy are merely a symptom of a more serious malaise: The country's state-led growth model is running out of gas. A recession or crisis may not be imminent, but the long-run implications are just as serious. Absent a change in direction, China may never become rich.

title: A Surf Retreat in the Costa Rican Jungle
summary: What began as a modest bungalow nestled in the lush jungles of Costa Rica's Nicoya Peninsula is now a rejuvenating, treehouse-like aerie with a surf-camp vibe. See inside the vacation home architect Alan Wanzenberg, whose clients include Mick Jagger. EVEN TRITE vacation-house names have uncanny staying power. So it is with Casa de Mañana, Alan Wanzenberg's home in the village of Nosara, a surf-and-yoga spot on Costa Rica's Nicoya Peninsula. Wanzenberg, an architect, is the Casa's third owner. When it was built in the early 1970s by Stevens Sperling, an American engineer and amateur naturalist, the bungalow offered a view of the Pacific from its veranda. Sperling positioned his drop-leaf desk in one corner to face the setting sun; Wanzenberg has replaced it with a dining table of his own design and added a weather gauge on a nearby wall (forecast: hot and dry from November to April; hot and wet from May through October). On certain summer afternoons, he stands and watches as water careens down the slope below. "It's a resilient landscape," he says. "Resiliency is pretty profound. There's a life parallel-the notion of sparse, severe moments and moments of lushness and fecundity."

title: Nancy Meyers on the Meaning of Home
summary: The director and influential interior tastemaker-plus five other luminaries-weigh in this month's Columnists topic: the value of home. "I grew up in a house that was a little bit like The Man Who Came to Dinner-we had a guest once who came for dinner and stayed for six months. Sunday breakfast was always a hub of activity. My bedroom was painted yellow, and to this day if someone asks me, 'What's your favorite color?' I say, 'Yellow,' even though I don't own anything yellow. But you can't escape the comfort of those kinds of feelings. I remember when we did Father of the Bride we painted the interior of the house very pale yellow. We must have done 20 different yellow tests. I see the word aspirational a lot when people describe the homes in my films, but the houses are meant to reveal the inner lives of the characters. Iris's house in The Holiday was cozy but cramped. She wanted more out of life. It's all a part of the storytelling."

title: U.S. Housing Starts Fell in June
summary: Residential building permits, which can signal how much construction is in the pipeline, dropped 6.1%. Home building in the U.S. declined in June, a fresh sign of weakness in the housing market.
